summary.p: Exchanged a son with the Zurich city clerk [Werner Beyel] for further education; asks Bullinger to allow the boy, despite his youth, to study Hebrew and Greek and to admonish him. Greetings. Leo [Jud] should also take care of the boy.

div.p: Greetings. We have exchanged sons, your city clerk and I. Therefore, he has received mine, and I have received his, both in good faith. As I have no doubt about his faith, I will sincerely uphold mine. My son has only lightly tasted three languages. However, I want him to nurture and increase his knowledge. He can be nourished in Hebrew through your sacred reading and deepen his Greek, if you allow it. Therefore, I ask that you not be annoyed by the boy's youth. For Christ also commended the little ones; he was far from being ashamed of children. You will therefore obtain from Mr. Theodor Bibliander and others that they allow him to be a listener. I also ask you to promise the boy that you will observe, with one eye or the other, how well and happily he spends his hours. Such a promise will undoubtedly ward off laziness and ignite diligence, and you will indeed do something greater than I can repay. But the best and greatest God will repay you.
Farewell happily. Greet your wife. I wish all neighbors near and far to be safe and sound.
Be so kind as to greet Leo Jud and ask him to also keep an eye on the boy. I seek nothing but that he learns for the glory of God and the benefit of others.
To the truly pious and most prudent man, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, pastor and bishop of Zurich, my most esteemed superior.
